title_sort: lewis k. brown to walt whitman, 10 july 1863
title: Lewis K. Brown to Walt Whitman, 10 July 1863
text: My Dear Freind[Friend] Walter.It is with mutch[much] pleasure that I take my pen in hand to inform you that I am well and that my leg is mending verry[very] fast I left Washington on the 2nd on the 6 1/2 O clock train but It was the rong[wrong] train and I had to get of at Haver de gras and stay all night on the Boat or els go on to Wilmington and so I got of and stayed on the boat and as good luck would have it I met 3 men on the boat that I knowed[knew] and they maid me verry[very] comfortable that night and then I left the next morning and got home in the evening and I gave Mother a verry[very] agreeable Supprise I was verry tired the next day but I feel well now. I think that I will soon get well hear for I have everything that I want we have a splendid garden and we have a good many cherries in fact every thing, the nice grain fields around the house and every thing looks so well. I have had a good many of my young friends to see me. I have got your picture and I am a going to have it fraimed[framed] the first time I get whear[where] I can have it don. I expect to go on a visit up to my GranFathers[Grandfather's] in about 4 weeks and I think that I will have a nice time up thear[there]. I only wish that you wer[were] hear I am sure that you would enjoy it for it is so nice or it appears so to me [w]ho has been pennd[penned] up in the Hospital for 10 months. My Father and Mother are well and send their respects to you for Mother says whoeve[r] did me a faivor[favor] or was a friend to me was one to her and you have bin a friend in nead[need] and that is a friend indead[indeed]. I expect that you still visit the Hospital if so give my respects to the boys I have nothing more to write at present so I will have to close hoping verry[very] soon to hear from you so good by and God bless you from your affectionet[affectionate] friendLewis K Browncare of James McPauley P.S. pleas[please] excues[excuse] this bad writing as well as spellingÂ  I have just herd of the fall of Vicksburg and I am g[l]ad of it and Simple Mead has drove the rebbels[rebels] out of Pennsylvania. Lewis K. Brown to Walt Whitman, 10 July 1863
